div.p: H75/11122, unit 816, VPRS 3991/P inward registered correspondence, VA 475 Chief Secretary's Department, Public Record Office, Victoria.

I have the honor to seek your permission of proceeding for a few days to the Murray River and the adjacent country, where I intend to examine the early spring vegetation before it dries up. Altho' I commenced my travels on the Murray in 1848, I am as yet unacquainted with many of the plants which appear very early in the season, and with their geographic range, altho' such information is required for completing my
in place of such deleted.
works. I should need, for the sake of instituting comparisons, to penetrate into a small portion of New South Wales Territory. If this proposition should meet with your favorable consideration, then I have the honor to request, that a free pass may be granted me by the honorable the Minister of railways for the Echuca line.
On 27 September 1875 the Under Secretary, W. Odgers, wrote to the Secretary for Railways: 'Please let [Mueller] have a pass for […] […] fpr Govt Botanist who is [travelling] on Official duty to the […] [3? words] for the Dept […] to free travelling'. [check this at PRO, p/c rather faint.
On [date unclear, check at PRO] [J] Steavenson, Secretary, replied by telegram: 'Passes never issued to Govt. Officers fares must by paid in usual way'.
On 29 September 1875 Graham Berry, Colonial Secretary wrote to J. Steavenson: 'Baron Mueller [requires] to proceed to the Murray on public business will you supply him with a railway pass. I will explain the matter […] when I see you.'
On 30 September 1875 J. Steavenson replied: 'The Commissioner of Railways & Roads directs me to forward a pass (enclosed) because it is asked by the Honorable the Chief Secretary. But he desires me to add that it is entirely contrary to the practice of the Department, and will probably lead to embarrassment in dealing with similar requests.' I shall remain in daily communication with my office and be able direct the work there from the country.

div.p:
Ferd. von Mueller
Attached to this file is an undated letter from M:
Sunday
Please, dear Mr Odgers, convey to the the honor. Grah. Berry my best thanks for his kindness of granting the Railway pass. I shall start to morrow.
With best regards
Ferd. von Mueller.
